content:
One can usually set up Thunderbird to look and act as they want it too while getting the benefits of more recent versions. What about the new “format” do you not like?

What do you mean that you crashed the hard drive and had to re-boot a new Windows?

If your old hard drive is unusable, probably all you can do is hire a data recovery service to salvage files that are salvageable. No guarantee that your local folders are salvageable.

Unless you backed up your data?

content:
I was not trying to solve your problem yet, just understand it. And either I missed your second message or there was a delay in posting my first message, so I did not understand all of your problems until today.

So you did not really lose your data. It is on an external drive. Then the solution to all your problems is:

  1. Copy your old Thunderbird profile from the external drive to ther right location on your internal drive. Although I don't use Windows, I believe that you should copy the profile folder to C:\Users\xxx\AppData\Local\Thunderbird\Profiles\. Look in that location on your external drive for your profile folder. The name is probably a combination of random letters and numbers, a period, and a date (unless you re-named it before). That's the folder that you want back on your internal drive.
  2. Tell Thunderbird that you want to use that profile. "Help" menu - "Troubleshooting Information" - "about:profiles" will let you select the profile to use.
  3. Re-start Thunderbird to open with that profile. (I think that this step is needed. Not sure.)

That process will restore your local folders, your layout settings, and everything else.

For future reference, you control the "format" things that you mentioned. Under the "View" menu, use "Layout" and "Folders" to set your desired options.
creator: mozilla98

content:
The Account Settings > Copies & Folders for 'Drafts' states where a draft is auto saved and it would be whatever is set up as the server default folder 'Drafts'.

So if you have a subfolder created in 'Drafts' which maybe you use for specific incomplete emails then when auto saving as a draft it will be auto saved in the 'Drafts' folder. This is the current situation.

Before you start to work on ProjectX draft emails you would need to alter the Account SEttings first. Account Settings > Copies & Folders for 'Drafts' to say: Select 'Other' and 'ProjectX on account name'

Then remember to reset afterwards back to Drafts.

A subfolder in 'Drafts' is just a subfolder and in profile it is stored as a separate mbox file.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If there is a way to identify Project X drafts, you might try a saved search to put them in their own sub-folder.

They would appear in the Drafts folder and in the Project X drafts sub-folder, they would be the same item, not duplicates.

Repeat for all drafts that you would like in their own sub-folders.

content:
At the moment it sounds like you are seeing a normal standard view.

The default order for a standard view (View > Folders > All Folders) is the following: For each mail account name folder: List of default folders - note some people may see 'Sent Mail', 'Spam'. 'Trash' as it depends upon whether using pop or imap and what names get applied by server. Followed by folders I created which will be in alphabetical order Example: > mail account name folder > > Inbox > > Drafts > >Templates > > Sent > > Archives > > Junk > > Deleted > > Bills > > Family > > Friends > > Thunderbird

Another alternative that some people use is 'Unified Folders' - this may be useful for people who have several mail accounts and want to see all incoming mail from all accounts being displayed in a single unified Inbox and same for all other default folders. View > Folders > Unified

Then you will see the same list of all default folders, but this time each will be a 'Unified folder' and each would contain subfolders of the various account. So a 'Unified Inbox' would have subfolders for each accounts Inbox. Below all the various Unified default folders will then appear the various mail accounts which contain all the folders you created in alphabetical order.

Regardless, the order of the mail account folder name will be determined by the order you have set up in the 'Account settings'. So in Account Settings, left pane, if you put eg: a gmail account at the top then you will see the gmail account at the top in the Folder Pane. You can use drag and drop of account name to move up or down to position.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
But you said : But for example Drafts and Sent were near the bottom,

Maybe you were using an addon to rearrange folders in an older version of Thunderbird and then updated which disabled old addons? Perhaps you were using 'Manually Sort Folders' but I do not think that addon has been updated to work on more recent versions. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/manually-sort-folders/ Works with Thunderbird 68.0 - 103.0

Another thought.... Perhaps you were temporarilly using a different view: Such as 'View' > 'Folders' > 'Favourites'
creator: Toad-Hall
